did.abstract: This collection of personal papers, correspondence, production files, radio scripts, autobiographical writings, interviews, speeches, articles, songs, clippings, photographs and visual materials provides a wealth of documentation on the personal and professional life of Pulitzer prize-winning playwright, lyricist, director, screenwriter, comedian and play doctor, Abe Burrows.

bioghist.p: Abe Burrows, playwright, lyricist, director, screenwriter, comedian and play doctor was born Abram S. Burrows on December 18, 1910 in New York City to Louis and Julia Burrows. His father was in the paint and wallpaper business. He graduated from New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn and attended City College and New York University first in a pre-med program and then studying accounting. In 1931 he was hired by a brokerage firm on Wall Street where he worked for three years. He then worked in his father's paint business and as a traveling salesman for a maple syrup firm. During summers he was a popular entertainer in the Catskills and found he enjoyed making a living with his humor.

Burrows began selling radio sketches in 1938 and for four years was a writer for Ed Gardner's Duffy's Tavern, 1941-1945. He also wrote pieces for CBS Texaco Theater, The Joan Davis Show, and The Ford Program. In Hollywood he became a hit at exclusive parties with his satirical songs and recitations with titles such as The Girl with the Three Blue Eyes and I'm Walking down Memory Lane without a Single Thing to Remember. During the course of his career, he appeared on many radio and TV programs, recorded two albums of songs and published An Abe Burrows Songbook. In 1948 and 1949 he toured the country performing in nightclubs and also had his own radio shows: The Abe Burrows Show and Breakfast with Burrows .

Burrows' biggest hits, however, were in the world of musical theater. At CBS in Hollywood he had worked for Ernest Martin who later joined with Cy Feuer to produce Guys and Dolls. It was Martin who brought Burrows to work on the Broadway show. The Guys and Dolls that opened in November 1950 with book and lyrics by Burrows and music by Frank Loesser, was an award-winning production and major hit that ran for years and was revived in London, on Broadway and on school stages around the country. Burrows' other major hit, again with Frank Loesser, was How to Succeed in Business Without Really Tryingwhich won the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1962.

From 1950 on Burrows' work was primarily for the Broadway stage as writer, director or both. In 1951 he doctored the musical Make a Wish, an adaption of Ferenc Molnar's The Good Fairy, and directed the revue, Two on the Aisle. In 1952 he was writer and director for Three Wishes for Jamie which he adapted with Charles O'Neal, in 1953 he wrote and directed Can-Can, and in 1954 he directed Reclining Figure. He adapted the screenplay of Ninotchka for the Cole Porter musical Silk Stockings and wrote the screenplay for Solid Gold Cadillacin 1955 and collaborated with Harry Kurnitz on Once More with Feeling in 1957 and with Richard and Marion Bissell on Say, Darlingwhich he also directed in 1958. He was also writer and director for First Impressions, an adaptation of Pride and Prejudice and director of Golden Fleecing in 1959, for Cactus Flower, 1965, for Holly Golightly, 1966, a musical theater remake of the film Breakfast at Tiffany'swhich closed before its Broadway opening, and for Four on a Garden, 1971 . His other directing credits include Happy Hunting, Golden Fleecing, What Makes Sammy Run?, Forty Carats, and No Hard Feelings. He was a director for Good News, 1974 and co-writer and director for Hellzapoppin', 1976, but left both shows before their openings. He also did some directing work on the show Forty-Second Street in 1981.

Burrows married his first wife Ruth in 1936. The couple had two children: James born in 1940 and Laurie in 1944, and were divorced in 1948. He married Carin Smith on October 2, 1950. Abe Burrows died on May 17, 1985 after a long illness.

scopecontent.p: This collection of personal papers, correspondence, production files, radio scripts, autobiographical writings, interviews, speeches, articles, songs, business files, clippings, photographs and other visual materials provides a wealth of documentation on Abe Burrows' personal and professional life. The early radio scripts of the comedian, the detailed files on each stage production especially Can-Can, How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying, and Cactus Flower, the large collection of opening night telegrams, and the extensive correspondence with family, friends and colleagues illuminate Burrows' personality and career. Includes long, informative and personal letters to his wife Carin when they were apart, working files for his Abe Burrows Songbook, 1955, articles, both published and unpublished, on show business and non-show business topics, sketches, notes and ideas for possible radio or television shows, movies or plays, various drafts of his autobiography, Honest Abe, 1980, caricatures and portrait photographs of Burrows as well as many shots of him with well known colleagues.

prefercite.p: Abe Burrows Papers, *T-Mss 2000-006. Billy Rose Theatre Division, The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts.

acqinfo.p: The Abe Burrows Papers were donated to The Billy Rose Collection of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts by James Burrows and Laurie Burrows Grad, the children of Abe Burrows, in 1999.

separatedmaterial.p: Audiovisual materials separated from archival collections are cataloged individually and can be found in the Library catalog. Search CATNYP, The New York Public Library catalog.

did.unittitle: Series I: Personal Correspondence and Other Papers

scopecontent.p: This series consists of personal correspondence between Abe Burrows and his wife Carin, correspondence with other family members, various materials documenting Abe Burrow's personal life such as holiday cards and gift lists, and condolences.

did.unittitle: Sub-series 1 - Correspondence between Abe and Carin Burrows

scopecontent.p: The sub-series is mainly long, handwritten letters from Abe to Carin when they were apart. The bulk is from 1948-1949 when he was on the road playing nightclubs and the summer of 1955 when he was in Hollywood writing a screenplay for Columbia Pictures Corporation. Also includes letters from Carin to Abe from the summer of 1955, poetry he wrote to her and notes and cards they exchanged. This is a rich file as the letters are long, informative and personal, shedding life on both Burrows' career and his marriage, and the handwriting is refreshingly clear.

This sub-series of personal material pertaining to Abe Burrows includes his selective service papers, a small file of correspondence and a matrimonial agreement with his first wife, Ruth (related papers can be found in Series X. Subseries 1. Personal legal papers), files on travel to Europe 1952-1953, and California 1955, Christmas card and gift lists, incoming holiday cards, address lists for parties he gave, thank you notes received for charitable contributions and benefit appearances, correspondence with purveyors about wardrobe items, certificates and awards (except oversized ones: see Series XIII.), printed invitations and programs, letters from unidentified correspondents (no last names), miscellaneous ephemera and inquiries from libraries about the future of his papers. Also contains 3 handwritten pages of journal entries titled Silver Hill Inn and dated March-April, no year, which may be Burrows' last written words.
Orders to report for preinduction physical examination and notice of classification cards.

Correspondence and telegrams document the life and career of Abe Burrows. While most family letters are in Series I, Burrows' personal and professional life were deeply intertwined; his colleagues were his friends. Thus there is not a clear divide between personal and professional letters, and many insights on Burrows the man can be found here.

arrangement.p: Letters are arranged alphabetically by correspondent and telegrams are arranged chronologically by production.

scopecontent.p: This sub-series of both personal and professional correspondence is arranged alphabetically with incoming letters and carbons of Burrows' replies kept together. Folders are for individual correspondent for prominent and/or prolific writers, followed by miscellaneous groupings for each letter of the alphabet. The letters range from substantive correspondence with colleagues such as Harry Kurnitz, Frank Loesser and Cole Porter, to extensive correspondence on arrangements and complaints with car rental agencies and department stores. Burrows was an inveterate letter writer and his many correspondents included Fred Allen, Steve Allen, Woody Allen, Mac Benoff, Richard Bissell, Bernard Braden, Art Buchwald, Eddie Cantor, Noel Coward, Fleur Cowles, Bing Crosby, Robert Emmet Dolan, Cy Feuer, Pierre Galante, Ed Gardner, Oscar Hammerstein, Julie Harris, Moss Hart, Lester Hyman, Belinda Jelliffe, Nunnally Johnson, E. J. Kahn, Lawrence Kasha, Madeleine Kasket, George S. Kaufman, Elia and Molly Kazan, Jean Kerr, Sidney Kingsley, Sam Levene, Art Lewis, Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse, Joshua Logan, Philip Malicoat, Groucho Marx, Ken McCormick, Shepherd Mead, Jo Mielziner, Edwin O'Connor, Richard Rodgers, Billy Rose, Sam Rosenberg, Harry Ruby, Phil Silvers, John Steinbeck, Jule Styne, Rudy Vallee, Herman Wouk, Maurice Zolotow and Albert Zuckerman among others. This sub-series also includes correspondence with professional organizations such as the Dramatists Guild.

In 1951 Burrows was subpoenaed by the House Committee on Un-American Activities and attempted to cooperate by testifying. He was not charged or blacklisted though in 1954 he still experienced some problems with potential sponsors because of the fact that he had been subpoenaed. His testimony, later statements, correspondence with his lawyers and letters he received from the public are filed here under "HUAC".

This sub-series consists of opening night telegrams sent to Burrows, grouped by production and arranged chronologically, 1950-1976, opening night telegrams sent to Burrows for radio broadcasts and night club acts, 1947-1948, miscellaneous non-opening night telegrams sent to Burrows, 1948-1981, telegrams sent by Burrows to cast members of his own shows, opening night telegrams he sent to colleagues in other shows (arranged by date), followed by other non-show related telegrams he sent, 1950-1968. The non-opening night telegrams Burrows received that were found interfiled in the letters sub-series were left where they were found.

The productions series documents the productions with which Burrows was involved, followed by productions he worked on that were never produced, then scripts sent to him for consideration, and lastly show business work not specific to a certain production such as contracts and correspondence for radio and television appearances and with recording companies, correspondence with agents, material on copyright, and papers on the producing/investing organization he ran with his wife: Beresford Productions.

This sub-series consists of productions for which Abe Burrows was a writer, director, or both or in one case (Make a Wish), play doctor and in another case (First Gentleman), an investor. Within each production the arrangement is: scripts, partial scripts, drafts and revisions, designs, notes, sheet music, contact sheets, contracts, correspondence, financial papers, programs, clippings and photographs.

scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, memos, contracts, financial statements and various reports relating to Burrows affairs outside the world of theater . With the exception of Sub-series 1. Legal papers which touches on both, most of this series relates to Burrows personal life, not his professional career.

arrangement.p: Organized in three sub-series: Sub-series 1: Legal papers; Sub-series 2: Financial papers; Sub-series 3: Miscellaneous personal papers on insurance, medical matters, taxes and homes.

scopecontent.p: This sub-series consists of correspondence, memos, contracts, and other legal papers with various law firms engaged by Burrows. The issues are both personal and professional including papers relating to his divorce from Ruth Burrows and personal legal affairs and wills of both Abe and Carin Burrows as well as correspondence pertaining to Beresford Productions, contracts with the William Morris Agency, testimony concerning Burrows' fall into an orchestra pit, and arbitration papers concerning professional disputes over various productions. Some of Burrows' carbon copies of letters he sent, especially to Martin Gang in Box 113, Folder 1, contain lengthy accounts of his working life. The legal files concerning Burrows appearance before the House Committee on Un-American Activities are filed in Series II. Correspondence because that is where they were filed when the papers arrived at the Library.

did.unittitle: Series XII: Photographs and Other Visual Materials

scopecontent.p: Photographs of Burrows are mainly formal portraits or photos of Burrows with colleagues on sets for television talk shows, at parties and formal dinners, etc. Includes photos of Burrows with Lauren Bacall, Milton Berle, Carol Channing, Marlene Dietrich, Moss Hart, President Lyndon Johnson, Steve Lawrence, Frank Loesser, Ethel Merman, Marilyn Monroe, Dinah Shore, Gloria Swanson Gore Vidal, Mike Wallace and many others. There is also a folder of the photographs used in his autobiography, Honest Abe which includes childhood and family portraits as well as duplicates of photos of Abe with some of the very well known people with whom he worked. The series also includes a few sketches and caricatures of Burrows. All visual materials in this series are small enough to fit in standard-sized hollinger boxes.

arrangement.p: Formal portraits of Burrows are followed by photographs of him at work arranged chronologically and then photos with others, mostly undated, arranged alphabetically by the name of the other, followed by family snapshots and photos with unknowns. At the end of the series is artwork, primarily drawings of Burrows by others.

scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs, artwork, certificates, an advertising mock-up for Abe Burrows Songbook and a souvenir program that were too large to fit in standard-sized hollinger boxes as well as posters for productions with which Burrows was associated. The artwork consists of caricatures and cartoons and a set design for Holly Golightly.

arrangement.p: Photographs (formal portraits arranged alpabetically by photographer, followed by photos of Burrows with others arranged chronologically); artwork; certificates; ad layout; souvenir program (3 boxes: 15 in. x 19 in. or less); followed by: photographs; artwork; certificates; theater posters (alphabetical by title) (2 boxes: 21 in. x 25 in. or less); followed by three items in map drawer.
